awd_titl_txt: Developing and Validating STEM Social Capital Scales
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will allow a mid-career principal investigator to acquire the education research expertise needed to successfully conceive and execute fundamental research with the potential to meaningfully advance knowledge on developing scales to assess social capital as it relates to STEM learning. The investigator's individual development plan includes a mentor and advisory board members with expertise specific to this topic who will provide guidance and feedback throughout the award period. Specifically, the principal investigator will seek to increase capacity in four major areas: (1) deep knowledge of social capital theories and measures; (2) knowledge and skills of designing and conducting interviews/focus/groups; (3) knowledge and skills of designing surveys and developing instruments; and (4) knowledge and skills of conducting validity studies and multilevel structural equation modeling. Activities in the individual professional development plan include attending academic conferences; engaging in one-on-one mentoring activities; participating in specialized training on scale development; engaging in networking opportunities; taking short courses and attending seminars; and taking part in online activities with STEM education experts, colleagues, and researchers. 
 
Through this project, the principal investigator will develop and validate two STEM social capital scales to advance knowledge about social capital's role in promoting positive students' outcomes in STEM. This is an important pilot study since few instruments exist to assess both student and parent perspectives about how best to support and promote participation in STEM. The project will be conducted in collaboration with a seven-week STEM summer program for students in grades six through eleven. Therefore, this project will seek to increase the principal investigator's understanding about student achievement, motivation, and participation in STEM fields and careers through a seven-step scale development procedure. Outcomes from this project will advance the principal investigator's methodological knowledge about the development of scales for measuring the influence of STEM social capital on student's interest, motivation, and participation in STEM fields and careers. The project is supported through the EHR Core Research Building Capacity in STEM Education Research competition that is designed to build individuals' capacity to carry out high quality fundamental STEM education research in STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM fields, and STEM workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview

This project aimed to explore how middle/high school students and their parents describe social capital in STEM, and to develop and validate new STEM social capital scales for students and parents. Phase 1 focused on student data collection and analysis, whereas Phase 2 focused on parental data collection and analysis.


Intellectual Merit

At the theoretical level, this project made a unique contribution to the literature on STEM education and social capital as it developed a novel conceptual framework of STEM social capital that integrates two dimensions (i.e., bonding and linking) and two forms (i.e., structural and cognitive) of social capital in STEM education. The empirical qualitative (more than 60 middle/high school students, parents, educators) and quantitative data (more than 2,000 middle/school students from two surveys) collected and analyzed through this project identified four major types of STEM social capital—instrumental, informational, motivational/emotional, and expectational—and five main sources of STEM social capital—parents/guardians, family members, educators, peers/friends, and e-community—for middle/high school students. At the methodological level, this project addressed one of the most current and critical measurement needs in STEM education research by developing and validating two new sets of survey scales. The first scale measures students’ social capital in STEM, whereas the second scale measures parenting practices in enhancing STEM social capital of their adolescent children. Both scales were tested with a large, diverse sample of students and parents. At the substantive level, the project findings indicated that historically underrepresented adolescents in STEM—including Latine/Black/Native American, and potential first-generation college students—reported significantly lower levels of various STEM social capital types, including instrumental, informational, and emotional, and STEM social capital is positively linked to STEM identity and career interest among middle/high school students. Moreover, the research results of this project showed that parents/guardians from various demographic and professional backgrounds broker diverse individuals and resources within and outside their networks to enhance the STEM social capital of their adolescent children, in addition to providing direct supports. 


Broader Impacts

The theoretical perspectives and empirical findings of this project have been presented at multiple academic conferences and invited talks, as well as have been reported in a series of journal articles and book chapters. By disseminating new knowledge and instruments of STEM social capital, this project promoted the use of social capital theories and measures for studying and understanding determinants, patterns, trends, and outcomes of STEM social capital, especially among middle/high school students, considering that most existing STEM education programs and research building upon the concept of social capital have primarily been focused on college students. In particular, the newly developed and validated student STEM social capital scale with robust reliability and validity as well as measurement invariance evidence across demographic groups has been modified and used by several STEM outreach programs across the country to monitor the enhancement of STEM social capital of their program participants both in in-person and online settings. The conceptual framework and empirical findings of STEM social capital generated through this project have also been cited by researchers in a series of studies on STEM social capital and by practitioners and organizations in various efforts of improving the STEM learning and participation of young students, especially among underrepresented groups. Moreover, through training and mentorship in quantitative and qualitative methodologies and STEM education research for several postdoctoral research and graduate students from diverse disciplines and demographic backgrounds, this project helped build capacity for conducting rigorous fundamental research in STEM education and for supporting excellence and equity in STEM education and workforce development.
